reviewText:
Awesome game, have'nt ploughed the hours into this like other MOW titles. However that is not to say this game isn't just as good as it predecessors. I stalled from buying this game for such a long time due to negative reviews and people rating it as 'too' difficult.

That is part of the games attraction surely, something that presents itself as a challenge? Single player the game is great but multiplayer is where it shines. On comms with a mate (or mates) this game is just as good as the other MOW titles. infact I love the weapons on offer. So it is more unique and in a very politically sensitive backdrop.

I would recommend this game as it is very much in th eflavour of all other MOW games, expect the high detail, anticipate the challenge and also the beautiful levels of micro admin. These series of games offer something very unique and it should be experienced with good mates who you can trust to run through in coop. Not some randoms who want to charge through it guns blazing. Digest the intel, scan the map and devise your path of action and you will be rewarded. Run in without covering your arcs and setting up fall back points for certain missions and you will fail miserably. COOP MP is a must, 4 of you working in unison is brilliant as you can set up multiple ambush points and often smash the enemy in one action, with a well coordinated strike.

A great game, as the rest.

reviewText:
I was willing to give this game a chance because it was only $8 and it was Vietnam themed. Loading up the first mission, I first realized that it was difficult to see anything that was happening. Which is a problem, because most of the map consisted of jungle and you're meant to manuever through it in order to avoid being killed instantly.

Nevertheless, I trudged on until one of my men suddenly keeled over after a short firefight. I shrugged and figured the game probably had traps as a mechanic since it's the Vietnam era, and sent another guy over to salavge the missing equipment.
Who suddenly keeled over as well. And at that point I realized that I could probably kill off my entire squad by doing that, which I promptly did to my own amusement.

I could see where this game might be fun for some people, but the average person isn't going to enjoy this. Even the average Men of War fan probably won't enjoy this. I have an affinity for both the Vietnam war and Men of War and I couldn't see myself putting up with it, if only because it's so difficult to properly navigate the levels, even without the addition of nigh-invisible booby traps.

Despite criticism, this game can stand on it's own merits very well.
It's very deep and challenging. The missions are long and complex but leave you enough room to improvise when things don't go according to plan. The difficulty is punnishing even on easy. You must save A LOT!

The graphics are surprisingly good, despite it's age. There are no noteworthy bugs to mention.
A great addition to the Men Of War series.

Alright, considering my last review was not well received for how dismissive it was, let me try this again but make it known just why this sucks.

Remember all the good things Assault Squad added to Men of War? None of them are here. Right mouse button being the move and action button like every other RTS made since the late 90s? Nah. Skirmish mode, with an AI who understands how to move its units around and a challenging, fun, and dynamic mode to play with friends? Nah. A campaign based both around the heroism of small units mixed with the grand scope and scale of an RTS game? Not really! (Note: that one was even in Men of War 1, so I have no idea why it isn't here)

Combine that with the lack of vehicles, the lack of any sort of mutable tactics from their WW2 titles (I.E there is nothing really here that screams Vietnam
date: it could just as easily be Men of War: Japan in the Phillipines") and you get one depressingly shallow cash in from the B developers of the Men of War series. Hell even for the B devs
